quoteFirst: We were about two miles from her, and the crew insisted that such a tremendous wave would be formed by suction as she went down, that we ought to get as far as possible away. The ‘Captain’ (as he calls Stoker Fred Barrett), and all, lay on their oars. Presently,
quoteLast: (2.15 a. m. per book account), as near as I can remember, we observed her settling very rapidly, with the bow and bridge completely under water, and concluded it was now only a question of minutes before she went; and so it proved. She slowly tilted, straight on end, with the stern vertically upward....
title: The Truth about the Titanic
author: Gracie, Archibald, 1858-1912

quoteFirst: The battle continued through the evening and all night till six o’clock on Monday morning. The artillery duel was at its height at
quoteLast: , and before that time a number of shells had fallen in the town, across which the batteries posted on the left flank of the French were firing. For the Germans the disadvantage of the position was that after leaving the shelter of the forest they had to advance for about two miles over an open plain, where they were exposed to the fire not only of the 75’s on the heights of Rixheim, but of the French infantry on the slopes below them, and here they lost heavily.
title: Verdun to the Vosges: Impressions of the War on the Fortress Frontier of France
author: Campbell, Gerald, 1862-1933; Mirman, Léon, 1865-1949 [Author of afterword, colophon, etc.]

quoteLast: , however, the excitement began to subside. President Barbicane reached his house, bruised, crushed, and squeezed almost to a mummy. A Hercules could not have resisted a similar outbreak of enthusiasm. The crowd gradually deserted the squares and streets.
title: From the Earth to the Moon, Direct in Ninety-Seven Hours and Twenty Minutes: and a Trip Round It
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905; Hildibrand, Henri Théophile, 1824-1897 [Engraver]; Bayard, Émile Antoine, 1837-1891 [Illustrator]; Neuville, Alphonse Marie de, 1835-1885 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Though I was the only visitor, I feared I should not have the bed to myself: so I e'en wrapped myself in my Highland plaidie (after the minimum of disinvestiture), and stretched my limbs on an arthritic settee, with intent to sleep. No sleep came till the quaffing roysterers of the clachan had ceased fighting under the moon outside,
quoteLast: namely. Rather than stay two nights in such a place, I boated out early next day into the mid-channel of the Sound of Mull, and clambered up the sides of Macbrayne's _Lapwing_, which took me to Oban.
title: Literary Tours in The Highlands and Islands of Scotland
author: Holmes, Daniel Turner

quoteFirst: The _fonda_ was less of an hotel than ever this evening, and we were warned that we must, willy-nilly, leave by the night diligence, because a _viajante_ (commis-voyageur) had engaged my room and would want to go to bed when the Fair meeting of the Commercial Club closed
title: My Spanish Year
author: Whishaw, Ellen M.

quoteFirst: “Why, what is wrong?” “So-and-so goes to sleep every night on the sofa in the ante-room, and as he never wakes up till between one and two o’clock, I cannot close the Mess.” “Sergeant, don’t mind him,--lock it up, and go to bed,” the officer replied; and so he did. Next morning
quoteLast: the honorary member awoke, and, rolling off the sofa, collided with the coal scuttle, and then fell over a high fender guard. This alarmed him considerably, and crawling away he clutched the legs of a centre table, which he overturned.
title: From Midshipman to Field Marshal
author: Wood, Evelyn, 1838-1919

quoteFirst: Beneath these kongs a fire is built on cold nights. It was at Tai Yuam Hsien, where he spent the second night, that Richardson, while sleeping soundly on a kong, was awakened
quoteLast: by being nearly baked. The coolie who was acting as stoker, had replenished the oven so generously with fuel that the bed resembled a crematory.
title: From Job to Job around the World
author: Fletcher, Alfred C. B. (Alfred Charles Benson), 1885-1928

quoteFirst: Catherine Camp to the village of Anzin, two or three miles north-west of Arras, with instructions to move again very early next morning. This we certainly did, as we rose
quoteLast: , and had finished breakfast by 3 a.m. About 6 a.m. we moved down to the railway line between Anzin and St. Aubin--Artillery Point was the name of the spot--and entrained.
title: The History of the 2/6th (Rifle) Battalion, "the King's" (Liverpool Regiment) 1914-1919
author: Wurtzburg, C. E. (Charles Edward), 1891-1952

title: My American Diary
author: Sheridan, Clare, 1885-1970

quoteFirst: Another sailor was called, but by this time the light had disappeared and the sailor saw nothing, and Columbus' hopes again sank. Still he felt they must be nearing land.
quoteLast: the commander of one of the other boats started the cry:
title: In Story-land
author: Harrison, Elizabeth, 1849-1927

quoteFirst: "September 28.--The heat is most oppressive: even the nights are hot, until
quoteLast: , at which hour a cool breeze springs up.
title: The Nile Tributaries of Abyssinia, and the Sword Hunters of the Hamran Arabs
author: Baker, Samuel White, Sir, 1821-1893

quoteFirst: Here no one could say where the 56th Division was, and I was directed to leave by a midnight train and to report to the R.T.O. at Abbéville. I got there
quoteLast: and was told to go back to Étaples by an 8 o'clock train that morning. I managed to get a few hours' sleep and breakfast at the Officers Club at Abbéville, and reached Étaples about midday on April 7. On April 9 I was told to proceed to St.
title: Q.6.a and Other places: Recollections of 1916, 1917 and 1918
author: Buckley, Francis, 1881-1949

quoteFirst: Later, at ten o’clock: “Complains of his paralysed arm.” “It is like lead; if it could only be cut off!” groaned Pasteur.
quoteLast: Mme Pasteur thought all hope was gone. The hastily written bulletin reads thus: “Intense cold, anxious agitation, features depressed, eyes languid.” The sleep which followed was as the sleep of death.
title: The life of Pasteur
author: Vallery-Radot, René, 1853-1933; Osler, William, Sir, 1849-1919 [Author of introduction, etc.]; Devonshire, R. L., Mrs., 1864-1949 [Translator]

quoteFirst: The intensity seems to vary with the temperature. The diurnal variation exhibits two periods of greatest and two of least intensity. In summer, the _maxima_ occur about 10 a.m. and 10 p.m.; the _minima_
quoteLast: and noon. In winter, the _maxima_ take place near 10 a.m. and 8 p.m.; the _minima_ near 4 a.m. and 4 p.m.
title:
A Treatise on Meteorological Instruments
Explanatory of Their Scientific Principles, Method of Construction, and Practical Utility
author: Negretti, Enrico Angelo Lodovico, 1818-1879; Zambra, Joseph, 1822-1897

quoteFirst: A few minutes later a stiff breeze sprung up from the southward which was a great relief to the heat-tortured keeper. The Indians, thinking him dead, left the lighthouse and set fire to the dwelling and began carrying their plunder to the beach, where they made off with it in the keeper’s sloop
title:
Historically Famous Lighthouses
CG-232
author: United States. Coast Guard

quoteFirst: “Why, what is wrong?” “So-and-so goes to sleep every night on the sofa in the ante-room, and as he never wakes up till between one and two o’clock, I cannot close the Mess.” “Sergeant, don’t mind him,--lock it up, and go to bed,” the officer replied; and so he did. Next morning
quoteLast: the honorary member awoke, and, rolling off the sofa, collided with the coal scuttle, and then fell over a high fender guard. This alarmed him considerably, and crawling away he clutched the legs of a centre table, which he overturned.

quoteLast: , and the _Alabama_ getting up her anchor, steamed out into the China Sea, by the light of the burning ship. We had thus lighted a bonfire at either end of the renowned old Strait of Sunda.
title: Memoirs of Service Afloat, During the War Between the States
author: Semmes, Raphael, 1809-1877

quoteLast: , as near as I can remember, we observed her settling very rapidly, with the bows and the bridge completely under water, and concluded it was now only a question of minutes before she went, and so it proved. She slowly tilted straight on end, with the stern vertically upward, and, as she did, the light in the cabins and saloons, which had not flickered for a moment since we left, died out, came on again for a single flash, and finally went out altogether.
title: Sinking of the "Titanic"
author: Mowbray, Jay Henry, 1869-1955

quoteFirst: I have no very clear idea of what happened next. As I had no knowledge of a motor I could but experiment, and finally
quoteLast: I did start the engine. I managed the steering fairly well after a time, and started back.
title: Tish plays the game
author: Rinehart, Mary Roberts, 1876-1958

quoteFirst: As usual we built a boma for the sheep, and George and I had our tent pitched, but El Hakim preferred to sleep in the open, so his bed was placed a yard or so away from our tent. After we had eaten we retired to rest, posting a sentry a few yards away. At
quoteLast: George and I were aroused from sleep, and considerably startled, by a yell from El Hakim, followed by a rushing sound as the sheep broke down their boma and stampeded, amid the excited shouts of the awakened men. Rushing out of our tent, we saw El Hakim, rifle in hand, peering into the darkness on the left, the tails of his shirt, his only garment, fluttering in the breeze.
title: An ivory trader in North Kenia
author: Arkell-Hardwick, A. (Alfred), 1878-1912
